content: The "Health Professions and Primary Care Reinvestment Act" is the short title of this legislation. It focuses on education and training for delivery system reform. The "Health Professions and Primary Care Reinvestment Act" focuses on education and training for delivery system reform, including a demonstration program for training in new competencies related to patient-centered medical homes. The "Health Professions and Primary Care Reinvestment Act" emphasizes education and training for delivery system reform, prioritizing grants for entities with a track record of training providers in primary care practice and underrepresented minority groups. The "Health Professions and Primary Care Reinvestment Act" prioritizes grants for training providers in primary care practice for underrepresented minority groups and vulnerable populations, emphasizing interdisciplinary collaboration among health professionals. The "Health Professions and Primary Care Reinvestment Act" emphasizes training health professionals in enhanced communication, evidence-based practice, chronic disease management, preventive care, health information technology, cultural competency, and health literacy. Amendments include authorizing $125,000,000 for this purpose. Authorized to be appropriated $125,000,000 annually from 2010 to 2014, with 15% allocated to physician assistant training programs for primary care practice. SEC. 3. HEALTH WORKFORCE INFORMATION AND ANALYSIS. The Public Health Service Act is amended to establish the National Center for Health Workforce Analysis within the Department of Health and Human Services. Its purposes include carrying out activities related to health workforce issues and collecting, analyzing, and reporting data in coordination with State and Regional Centers for Health Workforce Analysis. The National Center for Health Workforce Analysis, established within the Department of Health and Human Services, evaluates program effectiveness, develops benchmarks, and reports on health professional supply and demand to Congress. The National Center for Health Workforce Analysis within the Department of Health and Human Services evaluates program effectiveness, develops benchmarks, and reports on health professional supply and demand to Congress. It also establishes and maintains a national health workforce database to collect data on various health professionals. The National Center for Health Workforce Analysis evaluates program effectiveness, develops benchmarks, and reports to Congress. It maintains a registry of grants awarded and collaborates with various organizations for data sharing. The National Center for Health Workforce Analysis collaborates with various organizations to analyze health workforce data, including data from Medicare & Medicaid Services, National Health Service Corps participation, health professions education organizations, and other relevant datasets determined by the Secretary. It can enter into contracts for health workforce analysis activities. The Secretary awards grants or contracts to eligible entities for collecting, analyzing, and reporting data on health workforce programs and issues. This includes research on the supply, demand, and distribution of health professionals at the state, regional, and national levels. The Secretary awards grants or contracts to eligible entities for evaluating the effectiveness of programs related to health workforce issues and providing technical assistance on data collection and analysis. Eligible entities include States, workforce commissions, health schools, academic centers, and nonprofit entities. The Secretary may require information in a specific manner and time. Grants for longitudinal tracking systems must be increased, tracking individuals over a minimum of 5 years. A longitudinal tracking system must track participation in various healthcare programs and collect data on performance measures. It must comply with guidelines issued under specific sections. Entities eligible for an increase under this section must be recipients of a grant or contract under this title and have not previously received an increase. Funding is authorized for a national center for health workforce analysis and state/regional centers for fiscal years 2010 through 2014.
